questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Herbicides are used to control the growth of weeds. A herbicide that may be used safely with one crop species may damage another crop if the latter crop is planted in soil containing residual amounts of the herbicide from an earlier application. Two experiments were performed to study this effect.

Experiment 1

A botanist filled 90 pots with Soil Type 1. No herbicide was added to the soil in 10 pots. The other pots were divided into groups of 10 and the soil in each group was treated with 10, 20, 50, or 100 ppm of either Herbicide A or B. All other factors were held constant. Ten seeds of a corn hybrid were planted in each pot. After 40 days, the plants were uprooted, oven-dried, and weighed. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2

Experiment 1 was repeated with 90 pots of Soil Type 1 and 90 pots of Soil Type 2. The same herbicide doses and corn hybrid were used. All other factors were held constant. After 40 days, the heights of the plants were measured. The results are shown in Table 2.


Information on the two soil types used is given in Table 3.
questions.question: 1. The results of Experiment 2 indicate that, at every herbicide dose, average plant height was lowest under which of the following conditions?

choices.C: Herbicide A and Soil Type 2
choices.D: Herbicide B and Soil Type 2

Information on the two soil types used is given in Table 3.
questions.question: 2. Which of the following sets of plants served as the control in Experiment 1 ?

choices.B: Plants grown in soil treated with 10 ppm of Herbicide A
choices.C: Plants grown in soil treated with 10 ppm of Herbicide B
choices.D: Plants grown in soil treated with 100 ppm of Herbicide A

questions.question: 3. Which of the following best explains why the herbicides were applied to the soil instead of directly onto the corn plants?

choices.A: Corn plants are not affected when herbicides are applied directly on them.
choices.B: Corn plants usually die immediately upon application of herbicides.
choices.C: The experiments were testing how herbicides present in the soil affect corn growth.
choices.D: The experiments were testing how soil pH affects corn growth.

questions.question: 4. Assume that there is a direct correlation between plant height and plant mass. If Experiment 1 were repeated using Soil Type 2, one would predict that the average plant mass would be lowest under which of the following conditions?

choices.C: Herbicide A at 100 ppm
choices.D: Herbicide B at 100 ppm

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:

Experiment 2

Experiment 1 was repeated with 90 pots of Soil Type 1 and 90 pots of Soil Type 2. The same herbicide doses and corn hybrid were used. All other factors were held constant. After 40 days, the heights of the plants were measured. The results are shown in Table 2.


Information on the two soil types used is given in Table 3.
questions.question: 5. Assume that a second corn hybrid was grown in soil treated with varying doses of a third herbicide (Herbicide C). Based on the results of the experiments, what prediction, if any, about the effect of Herbicide C on the growth of this second corn hybrid can be made?

choices.A: Herbicide C would have no effect on the growth of these plants.
choices.B: Herbicide C would interfere with plant growth, but only at doses above 50 ppm.
choices.C: Herbicide C would interfere with plant growth at low doses, but have no effect at high doses.
choices.D: No prediction can be made on the basis of the results.

questions.article:

Information on the two soil types used is given in Table 3.
questions.question: 6. To investigate the impact of soil acidity alone on the effect of the herbicides on corn growth, the botanist should design experiments using soils of:

choices.A: varying pH, percent organic matter, and percent clay.
choices.B: varying pH and percent organic matter, but identical percent clay.
choices.C: varying pH and percent clay, but identical percent organic matter.
choices.D: varying pH, but identical percent organic matter and identical percent clay.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Two scientists discuss the possibility of accurate short-term earthquake prediction (accurately predicting a quake’s strength and location within hours or days).

Scientist 1
Short-term earthquake predictions can be made at the present time by detecting events that occur shortly before a quake. Rocks increase in volume under the great pressures often generated in fault zones. At the same time, numerous cracks open in the rocks. The volume increase can be detected by instruments installed near an active fault. Groundwater is often forced away from the fault by the expansion, raising water levels in nearby wells before a quake. The opening of cracks causes the speed of one type of earthquake wave to decrease compared to the speed that those waves had through the rocks before they cracked. Radon gas (a gas found in rocks in many locations) is released by the cracking, and the released gas can be detected by instruments.

Most quakes are preceded by foreshocks. Foreshocks are minor quake vibrations that occur minutes, hours, or days before the large quake. Monitoring seismographs (instruments used to detect vibrations along faults) for foreshocks can help predict quakes.

Scientist 2
Short-term earthquake predictions cannot be made at the present time with any accuracy. Long-term predictions (within 10 to 100 years) are much more accurate than short-term predictions. Many of the physical changes that occur in rocks under pressure vary according to the rock type or the variety of rock types that are present in a fault zone. Often, the expected volume increase happens long before the quake occurs, or it happens only moments before a quake. Changes in water levels of wells may be caused by factors unrelated to changes in rocks. The detection of radon is a process that takes weeks to conduct and obtain results. Many fault zones have almost constant vibration going on, and foreshocks are almost impossible to separate from these vibrations. One major barrier to short-term prediction is that we cannot directly study or sample the region 10 km or more below the surface, where quakes occur.
questions.question: 7. Which of the following ideas about short-term earthquake prediction was implied by Scientist 2 ?

choices.A: Short-term earthquake prediction will be possible in the near future.
choices.B: There are too many variables to make short-term earthquake prediction possible.
choices.C: Short-term earthquake prediction can indicate an earthquake’s location.
choices.D: Short-term earthquake prediction can indicate an earthquake’s strength.

questions.question: 8. A scientific article stated that “Humans will probably never be able to drill to a depth of 10 km.” Which of the scientists’ viewpoints, if any, is(are) in agreement with this statement?

choices.C: Both Scientists 1 and 2
choices.D: Neither Scientist 1 nor 2

questions.question: 9. Researchers testing the basements of homes in one area of a city found much higher levels of radon gas than the levels in homes in other parts of the city. Which of the following statements about this finding would both scientists most likely agree with?

choices.A: That area of the city will have an earthquake within 2 days.
choices.B: An earthquake will occur within 2 days, but the location cannot be predicted.
choices.C: This finding about radon gas levels may have nothing to do with earthquakes.
choices.D: Radon gas level changes are never related to earthquakes.

questions.question: 10. Scientists 1 and 2 would most likely agree with which of the following statements about rocks under pressure?

choices.A: Rocks under pressure exhibit an increase in volume.
choices.C: Rock volume increase is the only explanation for a rise in groundwater level in wells.
choices.D: All rocks are under the same amount of pressure in fault zones.

questions.question: 11. Which of the following procedures would be the best way for Scientist 1 to help test her hypothesis?

choices.A: Recording the strength of all earthquakes that have occurred in the past year
choices.B: Measuring rock volume increases and earthquake wave speeds in a single area not prone to earthquakes
choices.C: Measuring rock volume increases and earthquake wave speeds in many areas prone to earthquakes
choices.D: Mapping the location of all earthquakes that have occurred in the past 60 years

questions.question: 12. Suppose a new type of seismograph were invented that is capable of easily distinguishing foreshocks from other vibrations. This ability to easily distinguish foreshocks from other vibrations would:

choices.A: be inconsistent with the view of Scientist 1 only.
choices.B: be inconsistent with the view of Scientist 2 only.
choices.C: be consistent with the views of both Scientists 1 and 2.
choices.D: have no relevance to either scientist’s view.

questions.question: 13. According to Scientist 2, which of the following assumptions about rocks is a major flaw in Scientist 1’s view?

choices.A: All rocks react to pressure in an identical manner.
choices.B: The cracking of rocks causes an increase in rock volume.
choices.C: Radon gas is present in all types of rock.
choices.D: All rocks melt when subjected to pressure.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
Solar cycles are periodic variations in the Sun’s brightness.

Table 1 contains the date of onset for, and duration of, recent solar cycles; the time from a cycle’s onset until the Sun reached solar maximum (the maximum brightness for that cycle); and the number of sunspots at solar maximum.


Figure 1 shows the number of sunspots and the Sun’s brightness at a particular wavelength for part of one cycle.


For the same cycle, Figure 2 shows the number of proton events, when the Sun emitted much higher than average numbers of protons (positively charged particles).
questions.question: 14. The most likely reason that the data in Table 1 for Cycle 11 are incomplete is that:

choices.A: the omitted value was probably too small to be included in Table 1.
choices.B: the omitted value was probably too large to be included in Table 1.
choices.C: the Sun’s surface contained no sunspots during that cycle.
choices.D: Cycle 11 was still in progress at the time Table 1 was made.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:

Table 1 contains the date of onset for, and duration of, recent solar cycles; the time from a cycle’s onset until the Sun reached solar maximum (the maximum brightness for that cycle); and the number of sunspots at solar maximum.


Figure 1 shows the number of sunspots and the Sun’s brightness at a particular wavelength for part of one cycle.


For the same cycle, Figure 2 shows the number of proton events, when the Sun emitted much higher than average numbers of protons (positively charged particles).
questions.question: 15. According to Figure 2, the highest number of proton events in 1990 was measured during the month of:

choices.C: September.
choices.D: November.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
Solar cycles are periodic variations in the Sun’s brightness.

questions.question: 16. According to Figures 1 and 2, for the 7-year span between 1987 and 1994, proton events occurred most frequently when:

choices.A: the Sun’s brightness was above 90 units and the number of sunspots was below 90.
choices.B: the Sun’s brightness was below 90 units and the number of sunspots was above 90.
choices.C: both the Sun’s brightness and the number of sunspots were above 90.
choices.D: both the Sun’s brightness and the number of sunspots were below 90.

questions.title: passage III
questions.article:
Solar cycles are periodic variations in the Sun’s brightness.

Table 1 contains the date of onset for, and duration of, recent solar cycles; the time from a cycle’s onset until the Sun reached solar maximum (the maximum brightness for that cycle); and the number of sunspots at solar maximum.


Figure 1 shows the number of sunspots and the Sun’s brightness at a particular wavelength for part of one cycle.


For the same cycle, Figure 2 shows the number of proton events, when the Sun emitted much higher than average numbers of protons (positively charged particles).
questions.question: 17. Based on Figure 1, which of the following hypotheses best relates the number of sunspots to the Sun’s brightness at the particular wavelength?

choices.A: The number of sunspots is highest when the Sun is near its maximum brightness.
choices.B: The number of sunspots is lowest when the Sun is near its maximum brightness.
choices.C: The number of sunspots is highest both when the Sun is near its maximum brightness and when the Sun is near its minimum brightness.
choices.D: The number of sunspots is lowest both when the Sun is near its maximum brightness and when the Sun is near its minimum brightness.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
Solar cycles are periodic variations in the Sun’s brightness.

Table 1 contains the date of onset for, and duration of, recent solar cycles; the time from a cycle’s onset until the Sun reached solar maximum (the maximum brightness for that cycle); and the number of sunspots at solar maximum.


Figure 1 shows the number of sunspots and the Sun’s brightness at a particular wavelength for part of one cycle.


For the same cycle, Figure 2 shows the number of proton events, when the Sun emitted much higher than average numbers of protons (positively charged particles).
questions.question: 18. Based on Table 1, the onset of Cycle 21 will most likely occur during which of the following intervals?

choices.C: After 2150, but before 2200
choices.D: After 2250, but before 2300

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Because amphibian eggs lack a hard outer shell, their DNA can be damaged by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation in sunlight. Table 1 lists the egg-laying behavior of 7 amphibian species and the species’ relative ability to repair DNA damage caused by exposure to UV radiation.



Figure 1 shows the percent of eggs that survived to hatching in the lab for these 7 species after exposure to unfiltered sunlight or to sunlight from which the UV radiation had been filtered out.


Figure 2 shows predicted UV levels over time in 4 geographic regions that have amphibian populations.
questions.question: 19. Based on the information in Figure 1, eggs from which species are most likely to survive prolonged exposure to sunlight?

choices.C: Species F
choices.D: Species G

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Because amphibian eggs lack a hard outer shell, their DNA can be damaged by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation in sunlight. Table 1 lists the egg-laying behavior of 7 amphibian species and the species’ relative ability to repair DNA damage caused by exposure to UV radiation.



Figure 1 shows the percent of eggs that survived to hatching in the lab for these 7 species after exposure to unfiltered sunlight or to sunlight from which the UV radiation had been filtered out.


Figure 2 shows predicted UV levels over time in 4 geographic regions that have amphibian populations.
questions.question: 20. According to the data in Figure 1, which species showed the greatest difference between the percent of eggs that survived to hatching after exposure to unfiltered sunlight and the percent of eggs that survived to hatching after exposure to UV-filtered sunlight?

choices.C: Species E
choices.D: Species G

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:

Figure 2 shows predicted UV levels over time in 4 geographic regions that have amphibian populations.
questions.question: 21. Researchers recently discovered a new amphibian species that lays its eggs under cover. Based on the data in Table 1, the researchers would predict that this species’ relative DNA-repair ability is most likely:

choices.C: greater than 0.3 and less than 0.7.
choices.D: greater than 0.7.

Because amphibian eggs lack a hard outer shell, their DNA can be damaged by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation in sunlight. Table 1 lists the egg-laying behavior of 7 amphibian species and the species’ relative ability to repair DNA damage caused by exposure to UV radiation.



Figure 1 shows the percent of eggs that survived to hatching in the lab for these 7 species after exposure to unfiltered sunlight or to sunlight from which the UV radiation had been filtered out.


Figure 2 shows predicted UV levels over time in 4 geographic regions that have amphibian populations.
questions.question: 22. According to the information in Table 1, for all the species shown, as the exposure of eggs to sunlightincreases, the relative ability to repair DNA damage generally:

choices.C: decreases, then increases.
choices.D: increases, then decreases.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Because amphibian eggs lack a hard outer shell, their DNA can be damaged by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation in sunlight. Table 1 lists the egg-laying behavior of 7 amphibian species and the species’ relative ability to repair DNA damage caused by exposure to UV radiation.



Figure 1 shows the percent of eggs that survived to hatching in the lab for these 7 species after exposure to unfiltered sunlight or to sunlight from which the UV radiation had been filtered out.


Figure 2 shows predicted UV levels over time in 4 geographic regions that have amphibian populations.
questions.question: 23. Based on the data in Table 1 and Figure 1, amphibians that had the lowest percent of eggs that survived to hatching when exposed to unfiltered sunlight tend to:

choices.C: lay their eggs in deep water.
choices.D: lay their eggs in shallow water.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
Seashore cliffs often lose rock or sediment to wave erosion. Figure 1 shows cliff compositions; cliff heights, in meters (m); and the net change in mean high water mark (MHWM), in m, from 1880 to 1970 along a section of shoreline. A net negative change in MHWM indicates a net loss of rock or sediment and a net positive change indicates a net gain of sediment.




Table 1 shows the percentage of a year that vertical sections of a cliff are exposed to wave erosion.



Figure 2 shows Cliff E and F erosion rates, in cm/yr, as they relate to percentage of a year that a cliff section is exposed to wave erosion.
questions.question: 24. According to Figure 1, at a distance of 12 km along the shoreline, cliffs of what composition are present, if any?

choices.C: Cliffs of mudstone
choices.D: No cliffs are present.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:

Table 1 shows the percentage of a year that vertical sections of a cliff are exposed to wave erosion.



Figure 2 shows Cliff E and F erosion rates, in cm/yr, as they relate to percentage of a year that a cliff section is exposed to wave erosion.
questions.question: 25. According to the information in Figure 1, one property that was used to distinguish the various materials that compose the cliffs in the study area is the materials’:

choices.C: color.
choices.D: age.

questions.question: 26. Based on the information in Table 1, a cliff section with a height of 4.0–4.5 m above the zero baselinewould be exposed to wave erosion approximately what percentage of a year?

choices.B: force of waves on the 2 cliffs.
choices.C: distance of the 2 cliffs along the shoreline.
choices.D: annual rainfall on the 2 cliffs.

questions.question: 28. According to Table 1, which of the following figures best represents the relationship between the height of a cliff section and the percentage of a year that a cliff section is exposed to wave erosion?

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
Enzymes serve as catalysts (compounds that increase the rate of a chemical reaction but are themselves not used up) during digestion. The enzyme trypsin is involved in the breakdown of proteins into smaller subunits during digestion. A student investigated the effects of temperature, incubation time, and pH on enzyme activity.


Experiment 1
To each of 11 test tubes, 6 milliliters (mL) of a casein (a protein) solution was added. One mL of a trypsin solution was added to each of Tubes 1–10. Tube 11 received 1 mL of water without trypsin. The tubes were then stirred in water baths at various temperatures, and incubated (heated) from 0 to 15 minutes (min). After incubation, 0.1 mL of CaCl2 solution was added to each tube. CaCl2 stops the reaction and forms a precipitate (solid) with the protein that is not broken down by the trypsin. The precipitates were removed from the tubes and dried. The masses of the precipitates, in milligrams (mg), were measured to determine the relative amount of protein that remained in each tube. The results are in Table 1.



Experiment 2
To each of 6 test tubes, 6 mL of casein solution and 1 mL of trypsin solution were added. Tubes were adjusted to various pHs. Each tube was stirred and incubated at 25°C for 10 min. The relative amount of protein present in each tube was determined as in Experiment 1. The results are in Table 2.
questions.question: 29. In Experiment 1, which of the following conditions allowed the large amount of precipitate to form in Tube 11 ?

choices.C: Lack of casein
choices.D: Lack of trypsin

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:

The masses of the precipitates, in milligrams (mg), were measured to determine the relative amount of protein that remained in each tube. The results are in Table 1.



Experiment 2
To each of 6 test tubes, 6 mL of casein solution and 1 mL of trypsin solution were added. Tubes were adjusted to various pHs. Each tube was stirred and incubated at 25°C for 10 min. The relative amount of protein present in each tube was determined as in Experiment 1. The results are in Table 2.
questions.question: 30. In which of the following ways are the designs of Experiments 1 and 2 different?

choices.A: A larger volume of trypsin solution per test tube was used in Experiment 1 than in Experiment 2.
choices.B: Temperature was varied in Experiment 1 but held constant in Experiment 2.
choices.C: Incubation time remained constant in Experiment 1 but was varied in Experiment 2.
choices.D: The pH of the solutions in the tubes varied in Experiment 1 but not in Experiment 2.

questions.question: 31. Which of the following hypotheses about the effects of pH on trypsin activity is best supported by the results of Experiment 2 ? As the pH of the solutions increases from 4 to 14, the effectiveness of trypsin:

choices.C: increases, then decreases.
choices.D: stays the same.

questions.question: 32. Suppose that CaCl2 had been added immediately to Tube 16 with no incubation time allowed. Based on the results of Experiment 1, one would predict that the amount of precipitate formed would have been approximately:

questions.question: 33. In which of the following tubes was the greatest amount of protein broken down by trypsin?

choices.C: Tube 8
choices.D: Tube 10

questions.question: 34. According to the results of both experiments, one would predict that the LEAST amount of precipitate would be formed if tubes were incubated for 12 min under which of the following conditions?

choices.C: 30°C at pH of 4
choices.D: 30°C at pH of 8

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
Some students performed 3 studies to measure the average horizontal speed of a baseball along its flight path under different wind conditions.

In each study, a pitching machine, a catcher, and a camera were positioned as shown in Figure 1. A measuring tape was extended just above the imaginary line from the pitching machine to the catcher.


Study 1
When no wind was blowing, the students caused the pitching machine to pitch the baseball at a speed of 36 meters per second (m/sec). While the baseball was in flight, its image was recorded on the film in the camera every 0.1 sec. The resulting photograph showed 5 images of the baseball below an image of the measuring tape (see Figure 2).


For each interval defined by adjacent images of the baseball, the students measured the horizontal distance between the images (using the image of the measuring tape) and then divided the distance by 0.1 sec to determine the average horizontal speed of the baseball (see Table 1).



Study 2
When the wind was blowing from east to west with a speed of 15 m/sec, the students repeated the procedure used in Study 1 (see Table 2).



Study 3
When the wind was blowing from west to east with a speed of 15 m/sec, the students repeated the procedure used in Study 1 (see Table 3).
questions.question: 35. Based on the results of the studies, the horizontal speed of the baseball upon striking the catcher’s mitt was probably greatest in which, if any, study?

choices.C: Study 3
choices.D: None of the studies, because the horizontal speed was the same in all 3 studies.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:

Study 1

Study 2
When the wind was blowing from east to west with a speed of 15 m/sec, the students repeated the procedure used in Study 1 (see Table 2).



Study 3
When the wind was blowing from west to east with a speed of 15 m/sec, the students repeated the procedure used in Study 1 (see Table 3).
questions.question: 36. The average horizontal speed of the baseball for any one of the intervals (A, B, C, or D) was different in Studies 2 and 3. This difference was due to:

choices.A: a difference in wind direction only.
choices.B: a difference in wind speed only.
choices.C: a difference in wind direction and a difference in wind speed.
choices.D: neither a difference in wind direction nor a difference in wind speed.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:

Study 3

questions.question: 37. Given that an image of the baseball was recorded on the film in the camera every 0.1 sec, each photograph produced in the studies would have shown fewer than 5 images of the baseball if which of the following had been true?

choices.A: If the baseball had been pitched at a horizontal speed of 36 m/sec by a pitcher instead of by a pitching machine
choices.B: If the pitching machine and the catcher had been positioned so that they were 10 m apart rather than 18 m apart
choices.C: If the measuring tape had been extended just below, rather than just above, the imaginary line from the pitching machine to the catcher
choices.D: If the camera had been positioned at Point Y in Figure 1 with its lens facing south rather than at Point X in Figure 1 with its lens facing north

questions.question: 38. Suppose that prior to performing a fourth study, the students have reversed the positions of the pitching machine and the catcher. Assuming the baseball is pitched at a speed of 36 m/sec and the wind speed is 15 m/sec, the results of Study 4 will be the same as the results of Study 3 if Study 4 is performed when the wind is blowing from:

choices.C: north to south.
choices.D: south to north.

questions.question: 39. In each study, compared with Interval A, for Interval D, the baseball traveled:

choices.A: the same horizontal distance in a greater period of time.
choices.B: the same horizontal distance in a lesser period of time.
choices.C: a greater horizontal distance in the same period of time.
choices.D: a lesser horizontal distance in the same period of time.

questions.question: 40. In Studies 2 and 3, it took the baseball 0.51 sec and 0.56 sec, respectively, to travel from the pitching machine to the catcher. If these two studies had been performed when the wind was blowing with a speed of 20 m/sec instead of 15 m/sec, the respective times would probably have been:

choices.A: greater than 0.51 sec and greater than 0.56 sec.
choices.B: greater than 0.51 sec and less than 0.56 sec.
choices.C: less than 0.51 sec and greater than 0.56 sec.
choices.D: less than 0.51 sec and less than 0.56 sec.
